reviewText: As a 50th Anniversary special celebrating the series - it almost works.***SPOILERS AHEAD***It's fast, fun, funny and deals with interesting insider gimmicks and nods to the present and original series all over the place and fun to stop the frame again and again to pick out the little details (and one whopping one at the end - which, was a real pleasure to see) - it's special, looks great (this is a real test for a full feature length Doctor Who movie and not just a translation of the show) and the performances are very good nearly all around.But - and here's the problem - this less a special celebrating the series and more just a reset button for the series going forward.  After seven series of New Who it looks they realized they have painted themselves in a corner when it comes to telling new stories so, goodbye to the Time War and the Doctor's PTSD in dealing with it, as it turns it...it was all just an elaborate ruse by the Doctor (8.5) to fool himself into thinking he had killed not only the Daleks, but the Time Lords as well (well - more to the point - Time Lord children, there is not a thought spared for the adults at all, the children get all the flashbacks and tears here) and the years after, his distress, fear, hated of himself and growing anger towards the universe and his turn as the Time Lord Victorious are all just a fib.This is what really brought the special down for me.  It was no longer Doctor who?  But Doctor what? - exactly who is the Doctor now knowing that his efforts to stop the Time War actually...failed?  If you stop and think about it, the Doctor did nothing in the end.  The Daleks live (despite the rather clever crossfire resolution to the problem) and the Time Lords are now in a pocket universe waiting to be found and the Doctor's darkest day, his most brutal of choices, his forced hand to end the war and save the universe means nothing.  All his development towards being a better Doctor, a better Time Lord, and a better person are all based on a self-made lie.First rule: the Doctor lies - even to himself it seems.I was very surprised how neatly this was brushed away, how quickly it was swept under the rug and all the effort made from the 9th Doctor down has been suspended and I assume now erased.  But, in the end, it was a necessary evil on the part of the series to free itself from the baggage that they had been picking up and never paid off on.  River Song was really a bust, the build-up about Donna never followed through, the Silence never went anywhere and the Doctor's grave...well...we just learned the origin of Clara (The Impossible Girl) and nothing else.You'll notice I've said nothing of the Zygons yet and that's for a reason...why are they here?  I assume this will be an ongoing plot in the return of the series after the Christmas special, but, as for its place here, they are all set up and nothing more.  We learn nothing of the treaty at the end, we learn nothing of the Zygons end goals, we learn nothing of what happened to anyone - it's a loose thread of time and money that could have been better spent on just dealing with the three Doctor's.John Hurt is fine but his part his thin, which was a surprise.  The return of "Rose" was actually well done and a true surprise to me - I love the idea of a bomb that can talk itself out of being exploded; we are sure to see this device again as it never stated what happened to it after the non-Time War.  Both the 10th and 11th Doctor shine and it's their show - each work well against the other and solo as well and the 10th becoming Kind of England should have some consequences down the line.I don't like Clara - the actress is fine - but her part has never been fleshed out and I long for the days when the Doctor's companions were not sentient parts of time and space in a skirt saving the Doctor from himself all the time (if anything, Martha is the only one in the recent series that was not a God - Rose, Donna, Amy, River, Clara - all super powered beings, not a mortal among them and they each have the power to alter time and space - wrong - give me Martha any day, give me a new Sarah Jane Smith - give anything but another girl with Godlike powers, please).Overall - this special is special, don't get me wrong.  But as a story, it's clearly housekeeping - it's just brushing everything that has come before it under the rug and that's not special at all, that's just sloppy writing, simple choices and a GET OUT OF JAIL FREE card to the series to move forward...and I am looking forward to the new series, but I am not giving it any slack either.You get one and you used it - 50 is a good number to take stock and start something new, so run, you clever boy, and remember - you do have a history and it's worth remembering.

reviewText: This could have gone so very wrong. There are so many elements that shouldn't have worked, but in the end the Doctor's 50th anniversary was a rousing success. I'm going to start this review off by saying that I will offer no spoilers beyond the confirmation that, quite regrettably, Christopher Eccleston does not appear in Day of the Doctor. It is disappointing but thankfully Smith, Hurt, Piper, and Tennant more than make up for his absence.A phone call from U.N.I.T. sets off a fascinating chain of events that eventually brings 11, 10, and the Warrior together. The action is fast, the story is fun, the Doctors are an absolute joy to watch, and by the end of the special, the series will be headed in a bold new direction. There are several other surprise appearances that I will absolutely not spoil. Suffice to say that fans, new and old, will be very, very happy with them.This special was as close to perfect, without Eccleston, as it could get, though I do wish the villains were a little more threatening, though that is nothing more than a nitpick. Smith and Tennant are simply marvelous together, and John Hurt only makes them more fun to watch. All in all, The Day of the Doctor is a fantastic tale that no Whovian should miss.

reviewText: An entertaining 50th anniversary special, "The Day of the Doctor" brings together the 10th (David Tennant) and 11th (Matt Smith) incarnations of The Doctor together with the previously introduced War Doctor (John Hurt).SPOILERS:The War Doctor fought in and ended the Time War between the Time Lords and the Daleks by destroying the galaxy. "The Day of the Doctor" takes place in three time periods on two worlds--the 11th Doctor receives a call from UNIT when figures from a 3D painting depicting the end of Gallifrey disappear.The 10th Doctor tries to stop the Zygons from shape shifting into Queen Elizabeth (during the Elizabethian period) and changing the timeline.All three end up in the Elizabethian period to try prevent the Zygons from taking over Earth while the War Doctor debates whether or not to end the lives of two races as part of the Time War. Capped with an appearance by Tom Baker, the special does a terrific job of resetting elements of the series (and also sets up elements for Smith's Christmas episode that closed off his appearance as The Doctor).END OF SPOILERS:Featuring cameo appearances by a variety of past Who cast members, "The Day of the Doctor" looks exceptional in a 1080p high def presentation with a terrific 5.1 audio mix.The special features include two mini-episodes. The first "Night of the Doctor" features a surprise and delightful appearance of Paul McGann (the 8th Doctor who appeared in the TV movie "Doctor Who" from the 1990's). It provides a critical link the arrival of the War Doctor played by John Hurt.The second mini-episode focuses on the attack of Arcadia the city on the planet Gallifrey where the War Doctor activated the device to end the Time War.We also get a very good behind-the-scenes featurette on the production of the episode with plenty of comments from Tennant, Smith and the other returning cast members.This is a terrific 50th anniversary special and the mini-episode "Night of the Doctor" delightfullly ties everything together and allows McGann to appear as The Doctor again.Highly recommended!
summary: Blu-ray review: terrific 50th anniversary special allowing for cameos and a nice lead in to the Christmas episode
